name: db-st-pfv74
title: GKE Storage Tier Showdown: 4 Disk Types from HDD to Hyperdisk Balanced
description: Comparison: fsync-per-write vs no-fsync across four GKE persistent disk types (pd-standard, pd-balanced, pd-ssd, hyperdisk-balanced) on c3-standard-8 â€” measures how disk tier interacts with durability guarantees under sustained 60-second maximum-rate write bursts

hypothesis.claim: Hyperdisk Balanced delivers lower fsync latency than pd-ssd, which in turn beats pd-balanced and pd-standard. No-fsync writes remain uniformly fast across all disk types since they only hit the page cache.
questions: How does fsync write latency vary across four GKE disk types?
Is no-fsync latency truly independent of underlying disk type?
What is the sustained write throughput ceiling for each disk type under fsync?
Do node-level disk IOPS correlate with application-level fsync latency?
How does the fsync cost multiplier change across disk tiers?
Where does Hyperdisk Balanced slot in relative to traditional pd-standard/balanced/ssd?
focus: fsync latency distribution across 4 disk types
Hyperdisk Balanced vs traditional PD latency comparison
sustained throughput ceiling per disk type
disk IOPS correlation with application latency

disk_io_utilization.description: Disk I/O utilization (time spent doing I/O per second)
